name: Glute Bridge
description: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips toward the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top, then lower back down.
formTips: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement
Push through your heels to engage your glutes fully
Keep your knees in line with your hips
commonMistakes: Not squeezing glutes at the top
Pushing through toes instead of heels
benefits: Strengthens glute muscles for improved posture
Activates hip extensors which helps with daily movements
Reduces lower back pain by promoting proper pelvic alignment
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower your hips, exhale as you lift and squeeze
preparationSteps: Lie on your back on a yoga mat
Bend your knees and place feet flat on the floor hip-width apart
Position feet about 12 inches from your buttocks
Place arms at your sides, palms facing down

name: Donkey Kick
description: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Keeping the knee bent at 90 degrees, lift one leg until the foot is facing the ceiling, then lower without touching the ground.
formTips: Keep your core engaged and back flat
Focus on using your glute to lift the leg
Control the movement both up and down
Keep the working leg at a 90-degree angle throughout
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the leg
Lifting the leg too high and compromising form
benefits: Isolates and strengthens the glute muscles
Helps correct muscle imbalances between sides
contraindications: Wrist pain or carpal tunnel syndrome
Acute knee pain when in the quadruped position
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you lift the leg, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Position yourself on all fours on a mat
Align hands directly under shoulders and knees under hips
Ensure your back is flat (neutral spine)
Engage your core to stabilize your pelvis

name: Donkey Kick Pulse
description: From the donkey kick position with your leg lifted, perform small, controlled pulses at the top range of motion to intensify glute activation.
formTips: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the pulses
Keep the pulses small and controlled
Focus on squeezing the glute at the top of each pulse
Maintain the 90-degree bend in your knee
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement
benefits: Intensifies glute muscle activation through sustained tension
Builds muscular endurance in the glute muscles
Enhances mind-muscle connection for better glute recruitment
Helps develop the rounded shape of the glutes
breathingPattern: Maintain steady breathing throughout the pulses, avoiding breath holding
preparationSteps: Begin in the quadruped position (hands and knees)
Lift one leg up with knee bent to 90 degrees, foot toward ceiling
Maintain the lifted position with your leg at the top range of motion
Engage your core and keep your working leg's hip squared to the floor

name: Glute Kickback
description: From a quadruped position, extend one leg straight back and up, squeezing the glute at the top, then return to starting position without touching the floor.
formTips: Keep your leg straight but not locked during the extension
Focus on squeezing your glute to drive the movement
Maintain a neutral spine position
Keep your hips square to the ground
commonMistakes: Lifting the leg too high (past hip height)
Rotating the hip during the movement
benefits: Targets the gluteus maximus through hip extension
Strengthens the connection between glutes and hamstrings
Improves hip extension strength for daily activities
Helps develop the lower portion of the glutes
contraindications: Knee pain in the supporting leg
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you extend the leg, inhale as you return
preparationSteps: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips
Ensure your back is in a neutral position (not arched or rounded)
Engage your core muscles to stabilize your torso
Slightly shift your weight to the supporting side

name: Glute Kickback Pulse
description: With your leg extended straight behind you in the glute kickback position, perform small pulses at the top range of motion to intensify glute activation.
formTips: Keep the leg straight but not locked during pulses
Make the pulses small and controlled
Maintain a strong core to prevent back arching
Focus on squeezing the glute with each pulse
commonMistakes: Lifting the leg too high above hip level
Letting the hips rotate or tilt
benefits: Creates sustained tension in the glutes for greater muscle activation
Builds muscular endurance in the posterior chain
breathingPattern: Maintain consistent breathing throughout the pulses, avoiding breath holding
preparationSteps: Begin in the quadruped position (hands and knees)
Extend one leg straight back to hip height
Maintain the extended position without letting the leg drop
Engage your core and stabilize before beginning pulses

name: Fire Hydrant
description: From a quadruped position, lift one leg out to the side while keeping the knee bent at 90 degrees, then lower back to starting position without touching the ground.
formTips: Keep your core engaged to prevent torso rotation
Maintain a 90-degree bend in your working leg
Keep your back flat and head in line with your spine
Focus on lifting with the hip, not tilting the pelvis
commonMistakes: Rotating the torso as the leg lifts
Lifting the leg with momentum instead of control
Tilting the pelvis instead of moving from the hip joint
regressionExercises: smaller range of motion fire hydrant
benefits: Strengthens the gluteus medius, important for hip stability
Improves hip abduction strength and mobility
Helps prevent knee problems by strengthening outer hip muscles
contraindications: Knee pain in the working leg
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you lift the leg outward, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips
Keep your back flat and neck neutral
Engage your core muscles to stabilize your pelvis
Ensure your supporting hand and knee are firmly placed

name: Side Leg Lift
description: Lie on your side with legs extended and stacked. Lift the top leg up while keeping it straight, then lower with control without touching the bottom leg.
formTips: Keep your body in a straight line from head to feet
Lift the leg with control, avoiding swinging motions
Keep the leg straight but not locked
Maintain neutral spine and pelvis positioning
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to roll forward or backward
Using momentum to swing the leg up
Lifting the leg too high causing the pelvis to tilt
Not keeping the movement controlled during lowering
benefits: Specifically targets the gluteus medius for outer hip strength
Improves hip stability for better balance and gait
Helps prevent knee and lower back pain
Develops the side hip area for toning
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you lift the leg, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie on your side on a mat
Stack your legs with feet together
Align your head, shoulders, hips, and feet in a straight line
Support your head with your bottom arm, place top hand on floor/hip for stability

name: Side Leg Lift Pulse
description: From the side leg lift position with your top leg elevated, perform small pulses at the top range of motion to intensify hip abductor activation.
formTips: Keep the pulses small and controlled
Maintain a neutral pelvis throughout the exercise
Focus on using the side hip muscles, not momentum
Keep the leg straight but not locked at the knee
commonMistakes: Using large bouncing movements instead of controlled pulses
Allowing the pelvis to tilt during pulses
Letting the foot flex or point inconsistently
Rolling the hip forward or backward
progressionExercises: side plank with leg lift pulse
benefits: Creates sustained tension in the hip abductors for greater activation
Builds muscular endurance in the side hip muscles
Improves hip stabilization for better balance
Enhances the mind-muscle connection with the gluteus medius
breathingPattern: Maintain consistent breathing throughout the pulses, avoiding breath holding
preparationSteps: Lie on your side on a mat with legs stacked
Support your head with your bottom arm
Place your top hand on the mat or hip for stability
Lift your top leg to create a straight line with your body before pulsing

name: Dumbbell Donkey Kick
description: A glute isolation exercise where you hold a dumbbell behind the knee and kick the leg upward in a controlled motion.
formTips: Keep the knee bent at a 90-degree angle
Engage the core to stabilize the spine
Lift the leg using the glutes, not the lower back
Move through a full range of motion
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back instead of using glutes
Letting the dumbbell slip out of place
Dropping the knee too low between reps
benefits: Improves hip stability and core control
Can be done with minimal equipment
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift the leg, inhale as you lower it
preparationSteps: Start in a tabletop position on all fours
Place a dumbbell behind one knee
Engage the core and prepare to lift the leg

name: Dumbbell Hip Hinge
description: A foundational movement that strengthens the posterior chain by hinging at the hips while maintaining a neutral spine.
formTips: Keep the back flat and chest lifted
Push the hips back, not down
Engage the glutes and hamstrings to return to standing
Avoid locking out the knees
commonMistakes: Bending the knees too much (turning it into a squat)
Using too much weight with poor form
Not fully extending the hips at the top
benefits: Reduces risk of lower back injuries
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you return to standing
preparationSteps: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding dumbbells
Brace the core and keep the chest lifted
Engage the glutes and hamstrings before initiating the hinge

name: Dumbbell Hip Thrust
description: A powerful glute-building exercise where you thrust the hips upward with a dumbbell resting on your hips.
formTips: Keep the chin tucked and gaze forward
Drive through the heels to lift the hips
Squeeze the glutes at the top for maximum activation
Avoid overarching the lower back
commonMistakes: Lifting with the lower back instead of glutes
Placing feet too far or too close to the body
breathingPattern: Inhale at the bottom, exhale as you thrust up
preparationSteps: Sit on the floor with a bench behind you
Place a dumbbell on your hips
Position feet shoulder-width apart, knees bent
Brace core and drive hips up

name: Fitball Prone Kickup
description: A glute-focused exercise where you lie prone on a stability ball and lift your legs upward in a controlled motion.
formTips: Keep the movement controlled without using momentum
Engage the glutes and hamstrings to lift the legs
Avoid excessive lower back arching
Squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement
commonMistakes: Lifting the legs too high, causing lower back strain
Allowing the stability ball to move excessively
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Lie face down on a stability ball
Place hands on the floor for balance
Engage core and glutes before lifting legs

name: Squat
description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, lower your body as if sitting in a chair by bending knees and pushing hips back, keeping chest up, then push through heels to return to standing.
formTips: Keep weight in your heels and mid-foot
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement
Push knees outward (in line with toes)
Descend until thighs are at least parallel to floor
benefits: Strengthens all major lower body muscles
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you rise
preparationSteps: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart or slightly wider
Point toes slightly outward (about 5-15 degrees)
Engage core and stand tall with chest proud
Look straight ahead or slightly upward

name: Squat Pulse
description: Descend into a squat position, then perform small up and down movements (pulses) without returning to standing, maintaining constant tension on the legs.
formTips: Stay in the lower third of the squat range
Keep pulses small and controlled
Maintain weight in heels and mid-foot
Keep chest lifted throughout
benefits: Creates time under tension for greater muscle development
Builds muscular endurance in the lower body
Improves stability in the squat position
breathingPattern: Maintain consistent breathing throughout pulses - avoid holding breath
preparationSteps: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Lower into a squat position (thighs parallel to ground)
Keep chest up and spine neutral
Distribute weight evenly through feet

name: Chair Squat
description: A squat variation performed with a chair or bench behind you as a target and safety measure. Lower until your glutes touch the chair, then push back up to standing.
formTips: Reach hips back as if sitting down
Keep knees behind or in line with toes
Maintain an upright chest
Lightly touch the chair then push up - don't fully sit
commonMistakes: Using momentum to stand back up
benefits: Builds lower body strength in a controlled environment
Teaches proper squat depth and mechanics
Great for beginners learning proper form
contraindications: Inability to bend knees to chair height
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower toward the chair, exhale as you stand up
preparationSteps: Position a sturdy chair or bench behind you
Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width apart
Point toes slightly outward
Engage core and maintain good posture

name: Jumping Squat
description: A dynamic squat variation where you explosively jump upward from the bottom squat position, landing softly back into a squat to begin the next repetition.
formTips: Lower into a half-squat before jumping
Swing arms up as you jump for momentum
Land softly with knees slightly bent
Maintain core engagement throughout
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave in on landing
benefits: Builds explosive power in the lower body
Increases caloric burn and heart rate
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale forcefully as you jump
preparationSteps: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Position arms in front for balance
Engage core and maintain upright posture
Ensure adequate space above and around you

name: Lunge
description: Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about 90 degrees. Push back up to starting position and repeat on the other side.
formTips: Keep torso upright and core engaged
Step far enough forward that front knee stays over ankle
Lower back knee toward floor without touching
Maintain balance and control throughout
commonMistakes: Taking too small a step forward
benefits: Develops functional strength for daily activities
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower into the lunge, exhale as you push back up
preparationSteps: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain good posture
Keep shoulders relaxed and chest lifted
Focus gaze forward for balance

name: Curtsy Lunge
description: A lunge variation where you step one leg diagonally behind the other and lower into a curtsy position. Push back to starting position and repeat on both sides.
formTips: Step back and across as if curtseying
Keep front knee tracking over toes
Maintain upright torso and engaged core
Push through front heel to return to standing
commonMistakes: Not stepping far enough behind and across
benefits: Targets the often-neglected gluteus medius (side glute)
Adds variation to standard leg training
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you push back to standing
preparationSteps: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain tall posture
Keep weight evenly distributed
Start with small steps if new to the movement

name: Side Lunge
description: From a standing position, step one leg out to the side and bend that knee, keeping the other leg straight. Push back to center and repeat on both sides.
formTips: Step wide enough to feel inner thigh stretch
Bend working knee and sit back into the side lunge
Keep chest up and shoulders back
Push from the heel to return to center
commonMistakes: Leaning forward instead of sitting back
Allowing knee to extend past toes
benefits: Targets inner and outer thighs not hit by forward movements
Improves lateral movement strength and stability
Enhances hip mobility in the frontal plane
breathingPattern: Inhale as you step out and lower, exhale as you push back to center
preparationSteps: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain good posture
Keep arms in front for counterbalance
Distribute weight evenly between feet

name: Split Squat
description: A stationary lunge where one foot is positioned in front and one behind. Lower your body straight down and up without changing foot position.
formTips: Position feet hip-width apart, one forward and one back
Maintain a vertical torso throughout
Lower until back knee nearly touches ground
Keep front knee tracking over middle of foot
commonMistakes: Back foot positioned too close to front foot
Rising onto toes of front foot
benefits: Prepares for more advanced single-leg exercises
breathingPattern: Inhale during descent, exhale during ascent
preparationSteps: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Take a large step forward (about 2-3 feet)
Elevate back heel, resting on ball of back foot
Square hips and shoulders forward before beginning

name: Plie Squat
description: A squat with feet wider than shoulder-width and toes pointed outward. Lower your body straight down then push back up, focusing on inner thighs and glutes.
formTips: Turn toes out to about 45 degrees
Take a wide stance (wider than shoulders)
Keep knees tracking in direction of toes
Maintain upright torso and engaged core
benefits: Targets inner thighs (adductors) more than traditional squats
Provides variation to standard leg training
breathingPattern: Inhale during descent, exhale during ascent
preparationSteps: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart
Turn toes outward at 45-degree angles
Engage core and maintain tall posture
Hold hands in front of body for balance if needed

name: Pistol Box Squat
description: A modified single-leg squat where you lower on one leg until you touch a box or bench, using it as depth gauge and safety. Rise back up using primarily the working leg.
formTips: Keep working foot flat on ground
Extend non-working leg forward
Lower controlled until glutes touch box/bench
Minimize pushing through supporting hand if using one
commonMistakes: Sitting completely onto box rather than tapping
Distributing too much weight to supporting hand
benefits: Identifies and addresses leg strength imbalances
Progresses toward the challenging pistol squat
breathingPattern: Inhale during descent, exhale during the ascent
preparationSteps: Place a box, bench or chair at appropriate height
Stand on one leg in front of the box
Extend other leg forward, slightly off ground
Use hands for balance if needed (in front or lightly touching support)

name: Step Up Exercise
description: Stand in front of a step or bench. Place one foot on the step and push through that heel to lift your body up, bringing the other foot up. Step back down and repeat, alternating legs.
formTips: Place entire foot on step, not just toes
Push through heel of stepping foot
Drive knee up on non-stepping leg for full range
Maintain upright posture throughout
commonMistakes: Pushing off back foot instead of front foot
Using momentum instead of controlled strength
benefits: Builds functional strength for daily activities (climbing stairs)
Low impact compared to jumping exercises
contraindications: Knee pain when bearing weight on bent knee
breathingPattern: Inhale before stepping up, exhale as you push up to standing
preparationSteps: Find a sturdy step, bench or box (6-12 inches high)
Stand directly in front of it, about a foot away
Position feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain good posture

name: Wall Sit
description: An isometric exercise where you position your back against a wall and lower until thighs are parallel to the ground, holding this seated position without actual seat support.
formTips: Position back flat against wall
Lower until thighs are parallel to ground
Keep knees directly above ankles (90-degree angle)
Distribute weight evenly across entire foot
commonMistakes: Sliding down too low (knees beyond 90 degrees)
Allowing hips to drop below knees
Arching lower back away from wall
benefits: Builds isometric strength and endurance in leg muscles
Improves knee stability and quad strength
Develops mental fortitude through static holding
Creates time under tension for muscle development
breathingPattern: Maintain regular breathing throughout the hold - avoid holding breath
preparationSteps: Find a flat, sturdy wall
Stand with your back against the wall, feet hip-width apart
Step feet forward about 2 feet from the wall
Brace core and prepare for the slide down

name: Dumbbell Calf Raise
description: A standing exercise where you lift your heels off the ground while holding dumbbells, engaging the calf muscles.
formTips: Keep feet hip-width apart
Rise onto the balls of your feet slowly
Lower heels down with control
Engage core to maintain balance
commonMistakes: Bouncing up and down too quickly
Not achieving full range of motion
breathingPattern: Inhale while lowering, exhale while rising
preparationSteps: Stand tall with dumbbells in each hand
Position feet shoulder-width apart
Engage core and maintain upright posture

name: Dumbbell Jumping Squat
description: A dynamic exercise combining a squat with an explosive jump, using dumbbells for added resistance.
formTips: Keep chest up and back straight
Engage core to maintain stability
Land softly to reduce impact on joints
Ensure knees track over toes
commonMistakes: Not fully extending in the jump
breathingPattern: Inhale as you squat, exhale as you jump
preparationSteps: Hold dumbbells at your sides
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Engage core and maintain neutral spine

name: Dumbbell Lunge
description: A lower-body strength exercise that involves stepping forward into a lunge position while holding dumbbells.
formTips: Keep torso upright throughout
Step forward with control
Ensure knee does not extend past toes
Push through heel to return to standing
breathingPattern: Inhale as you step forward, exhale as you push back
preparationSteps: Hold dumbbells at your sides
Stand with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain an upright posture

name: Dumbbell Plie Squat
description: A squat variation with a wide stance, focusing on inner thighs and glutes.
formTips: Keep feet wider than shoulder-width
Point toes slightly outward
Keep chest up and back straight
Engage inner thighs throughout movement
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you stand
preparationSteps: Hold a dumbbell with both hands in front
Stand with a wide stance and toes slightly turned out
Engage core before lowering into squat

name: Dumbbell Single Leg Deadlift
description: A balance-focused deadlift variation where one leg extends back while lowering dumbbells to engage hamstrings and glutes.
formTips: Keep back straight and core engaged
Hinge at hips while keeping a slight knee bend
Extend back leg for balance
Slowly return to starting position
commonMistakes: Losing balance due to improper core engagement
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you return to standing
preparationSteps: Hold a dumbbell in each hand
Stand with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and keep shoulders back

name: Fitball Alternating Leg Raise
description: A core and leg exercise performed on a stability ball to enhance lower body strength and balance.
formTips: Keep hips stable while raising one leg
Squeeze glutes at the top
Control the movement throughout
breathingPattern: Inhale as you prepare, exhale as you lift the leg
preparationSteps: Lie on a stability ball with feet on the floor
Engage core and squeeze glutes
Lift one leg while keeping balance

name: Leg Lifts with Resistance Band
description: A resistance-based leg lift exercise targeting hip flexors, glutes, and thighs.
formTips: Keep core engaged throughout
Control the motion while lifting and lowering
Keep resistance band taut for maximum activation
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement
breathingPattern: Exhale as you lift the leg, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Wrap resistance band around both legs
Lie flat on your back with legs extended
Lift one leg while keeping the other stable

name: Fitball Single Leg Roll
description: A stability ball exercise that challenges hamstrings and core by rolling the ball with one leg while keeping the other lifted.
formTips: Keep hips stable throughout the movement
Engage core for balance
Roll the ball smoothly without jerking
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement
breathingPattern: Exhale as you roll the ball in, inhale as you extend
preparationSteps: Lie on your back with heels on the ball
Lift one leg while the other stays on the ball
Engage core and roll ball towards glutes

name: Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise
description: A standing calf exercise that strengthens the lower legs by raising onto the balls of the feet while holding dumbbells.
formTips: Engage core for balance
Raise heels as high as possible
Lower heels slowly for full range of motion
commonMistakes: Not fully extending calves at the top
breathingPattern: Exhale as you raise, inhale as you lower
preparationSteps: Hold dumbbells at your sides
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Engage core and lift heels

name: Barbell Hip Thrust
description: An advanced glute-focused exercise where you thrust your hips upward while supporting a barbell across your hips.
formTips: Place a pad between the barbell and your hips for comfort
Keep chin tucked throughout the movement
Drive through heels and squeeze glutes at the top
Keep your back in a neutral position
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back at the top
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
breathingPattern: Inhale at the bottom, exhale forcefully as you thrust upward
preparationSteps: Sit on the floor with your upper back against a bench
Roll the barbell over your legs to your hip crease
Feet flat on floor, shoulder-width apart
Brace core before initiating movement

name: Barbell Squat
description: A fundamental compound exercise targeting multiple lower body muscles with emphasis on the glutes, quadriceps, and hamstrings.
formTips: Keep chest up and back neutral
Push knees out in line with toes
Descend until thighs are at least parallel to ground
Drive through heels on the way up
Keep the barbell centered over mid-foot
commonMistakes: Rising onto toes instead of staying flat-footed
Looking up instead of keeping neutral neck position
breathingPattern: Big breath at the top, hold during descent, exhale forcefully after passing sticking point on the way up
preparationSteps: Position bar at upper back/rear delts (high bar) or lower on rear delts (low bar)
Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder width
Unrack the bar by extending legs and stepping back
Set feet shoulder-width or slightly wider apart
Brace core before initiating descent

name: Barbell Romanian Deadlift
description: A hip-hinge movement that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes while maintaining a neutral spine.
formTips: Maintain slight bend in knees throughout movement
Keep back flat and chest up
Push hips back as far as possible
Lower bar close to legs
Feel a stretch in hamstrings at bottom position
commonMistakes: Not pushing hips back far enough
Allowing bar to drift away from legs
breathingPattern: Breathe in at the top, hold during descent, exhale on the way up
preparationSteps: Begin standing with barbell at hip level
Grip slightly wider than shoulder width
Set feet hip-width apart
Engage lats and brace core
Initiate movement by pushing hips back

name: Bulgarian Split Squat
description: A unilateral lower body exercise that targets the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings while improving balance and stability.
formTips: Keep torso upright
Front knee should track in line with foot
Lower until front thigh is parallel to ground
Maintain balance by focusing on a fixed point
Keep weight centered over front foot
commonMistakes: Placing back foot too close or too far from bench
Rising onto toes of front foot
benefits: Minimizes lower back stress compared to bilateral exercises
breathingPattern: Inhale during descent, exhale during ascent
preparationSteps: Stand about 2-3 feet in front of a bench
Place one foot behind you on the bench
Square hips forward
Hold weights at sides if using
Brace core before beginning movement

name: Banded Hip Abduction
description: An isolation exercise that specifically targets the gluteus medius and minimus muscles using a resistance band.
formTips: Keep movement controlled and deliberate
Avoid rotating at the hip
Maintain neutral spine position
Feel the contraction in the side of the hip
Keep tension in the band throughout the movement
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control
Leaning to the side during movement
Not maintaining consistent tension in the band
benefits: Strengthens hip abductors for better stability
Enhances knee stability during walking and running
breathingPattern: Exhale during abduction, inhale during return
preparationSteps: Loop resistance band around both legs just above the knees
Stand with feet hip-width apart
Slight bend in knees
Engage core and maintain neutral spine
Hands on hips or holding onto a stable surface for balance
